El préstamo que esta solicitando a CREDICAMPO, es para proceso de legalización de una escritura de su propiedad, específicamente para cancelar el costo de la elaboración del documento por parte de un profesional en la materia. Esto le permitirá tener legal su propiedad y tener un documento que le respalde ser propietaria de la propiedad que hace varios años quería legalizar.

Irma desea tener un mejor trabajo que sea de tiempo completo, de esta manera mejorar su condición de vida para ella y su familia, vivir cómodamente en una casa digna para su familia, desea también seguir estudiando en el futuro para tener un mejor empleo, casarse y formar un hogar digno para ella y tener 2 hijos que le puedan ayudar en el futuro. Todo esto lo lograra con mucho esfuerzo, trabajo y con futuros créditos que solicitara.
texts.en:
Irma is 33 years old and completed up to third year of high school. She is single and does not have children. She lives with her parents and her 16-year-old nephew, who is in high school. Irma has been working as an administrative assistant in a health centre for two years. Her parents and nephew are the only ones who depend on Irma.

Irma works only on weekends, as that is what is set out in her contract. Irma was given this opportunity to work at the health centre.  Before, she looked after the home. Irma lives very close to her work - it is only 100m away. Irma walks to work, which she starts at 6pm and finished at 4pm.

Irma is applying for a CREDICAMPO loan in order to legalise a deed on her property. Irma wants to cover the costs of this legalisation by a professional. This will allow Irma to have her property completely legal and she will have a document confirming she is the owner. She has wanted to do this for some years.

Irma wants a better, full-time job. With it she could improve her and her family's living conditions and live comfortably in a decent house. In the future Irma also wants to continue studying in order to have a better job, to marry and to start a home. She also wants to have two children who can help her in the future. Irma will achieve all of this with a lot of effort, hard-work and with future loans.

loans.use: to cover the costs of a legal document for her property.

loans.name: Dúo San Marcos Group

texts.es:
DUO SAN MARCOS
Está integrado por Maria Elena, ella es  originaria de Sumpango, se dedica a vender refacciones diariamente  y también se dedica  elaborar tejidos ella le da gracias a Dios ya que su negocio ha crecido gracias a la ayuda de kiva, es el tercer crédito que solicita y gracias a Dios está pagando muy bien y  no callo en mora ella promete cumplir con sus pagos  si se les otorgara otro crédito.
texts.en:
"San Marcos" duo

One member of this duo is Maria Elena, who is originally from Sumpango. She makes a living selling light refreshments, as well as knitted products. Maria thanks God that her business has grown with Kiva's help. This is her third loan and, thanks to God, she is paying them off and hasn't fallen behind on repayments. Maria promises to make her repayments if this loan is granted.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for making food.

loans.name: Nen

texts.en:
Originally from a rural village of the Cheung Prey district of Kampong Cham province, Nen is a 30-year-old married mother of two kids. Rice farming has been the main source of her family’s income for 10 years and to better support the family and help to earn more income, her husband works as a paid motor-taxi driver. Together, they can earn about 34,000 KHR per day to meet family’s needs and manage to save about 15,000 KHR each day for the future needs. 

Nen is a second-cycled client with VisionFund and completely repaid the previous loan. The first loan has helped Nen better support her family members. 

Now she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to grow her rice fruitfully and healthily and also hopes to make more income to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Xejuyup Group

texts.es:
Antonia (segunda de derecha a izquierda en la  fotografía) es una señora de 34 años de edad, casada, tiene dos hijos, vive junto a ellos en Nahualá, Sololá.
Ella se dedica a la producción y venta de banano, lo cual lo realiza en la comunidad donde vive; esta actividad la aprendió de su familia, quienes se dedican a lo mismo desde muchos años atrás. Esta labor le generan a ella los ingresos necesarios que le permiten darle lo necesario a su familia. Tiene más de 15 años de experiencia en esta actividad.
Ella decidió organizar un grupo con el objetivo de ayudarse mutuamente con su compañeras y asi mejorar sus niveles de vida. Utilizará el préstamo para la compra de insumos (fertilizante y pago de mano de obra) para mantenimiento de las  plantaciones de banano.
El sueño más importante de doña Antonia es comprar más terrenos y asi incrementar sus plantaciones de  banano.
texts.en:
Antonia (second on the right in the photo) is 34 years old, married and has two children. She lives with her children in Nahualá, in Sololá.

Antonia makes a living growing and selling bananas in her home community. She learned this trade from her family who, many years ago, did this work. This work generates the necessary income for Antonia to give her family everything that they need. Antonia has been doing this work for over 15 years.

Antonia decided to organise a loan group in order for the members to help each other and improve their lifestyles. Antonia will use this loan in order to buy supplies (fertiliser) and to pay labourers, in order to look after her banana plantations.

Antonia's biggest dream is to buy more land and increase her banana crops.

loans.use: to buy supplies (fertilisers) and to pay labourers.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.es:
Ella es geraldine tiene 16 años, los papas de ella fallecieron, ella trabaja los fines de semana, el apoyo que ella tiene en este momento solo son los padrinos, el proyecto de vida es seguir estudiando para poder ser docente, ya que le gusta trabajar con niños y con eso puede lograr un futuro exitoso.

Esta estudiando en campo alto y se entero del  convenio que están manejando llamado kiva,  a ella le queda muy complicado pagar la cuota completa, por esa razón pide a kiva la colaboración para poder terminar los estudios en campo alto.
texts.en:
This is 16-year-old Geraldine. Her parents died and she works at the weekend. She receives support only from her godparents. Her plan is to continue studying in order to be a teacher as she likes working with children and this will make her successful in the future.

Geraldine is studying in Campo Alto and heard about the Kiva loans. It is very difficult very Geraldine to be able to pay all of her tuition fees alone so is applying for support from Kiva in order to finish her studies at Campo Alto

loans.use: to pay tuition fees for one semester.

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en:
Tahira is a 29-year-old lady, her residence is in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of three children; her husband owns a furniture shop in which he manufactures beds, sofa’s, tables and chairs. He has been making furniture for many years; his practice is to make furniture and then polish the furniture so it is well finished. Polish increases the shine, grace and is valuable in the long run.

The demand for manufacturing suddenly increased and her husband has spent all his money to buy raw materials instead of furniture polish. Now he does not have enough cash in hand to buy his remaining raw materials.

Therefore Tahira requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan so that her husband will be able to buy polish, a spray gun and kerosene oil. Tahira is very thankful to Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan for this honorable support.

loans.use: To buy polish, a spray gun and kerosene oil for polishing furniture.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 42 years old from Naivasha and is married. They have four children who are aged between 10 and three years old.

Peter has a livestock business that he has been doing for the past five years and has applied for his first loan from VisionFund Kenya to enable him to buy more sheep for fattening. He is optimistic that his business will do better after the loan. 

He hopes to expand his business in the near future and be able to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy sheep.

loans.name: Phen's Group

texts.en:
Residing in a rural village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Phen is aged 60 years and married. She has four children. To support the family, she and her husband have been in farming rice for 35 years. To supplement their income, she also works for others for a fee. The current business earns her family about 27,000 KHR per day to meet her family’s needs. 

Phen has been a member of Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for seven cycles already and she successfully used the past loans to better support her family to have sufficient food. Now she and her group member are applying for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to plow the rice field. She hopes to grow more crops so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to plow the rice field.

loans.name: Shahida

texts.en:
Shahida belongs to a poor family, living with her spouse and five children in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband is a blacksmith; he manufactures iron accessories such as doors and windows which are used in houses. He has been providing door-to-door services to weld broken accessories as well.

A few days ago his welding machine become out of order due to overheating and it needs to be replaced with new one. He wants to buy a new welding machine but he does not have cash in hand due to lots of household expenses. 

Therefore Shahida requested a loan from BRAC who is an active field partner of Kiva, so that her husband will be able to buy a welding machine for his business. Shahida thanks Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine.

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Mrs. Nergui, 53 years old, lives alone in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She resides in a Mongolian traditional ger (portable felt dwelling) on a plot of land. She has been making and selling metal nails to local people since 2002. 

Using her previous loan, she imported metal from China and it greatly increased her profit. So she decided to import metal again from China and for this cause she is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 MNT. As a result, she can invest in her children's education. The borrower is one of our most reliable clients as she paid each installment without any delay in her ongoing credit history.

loans.use: to buy raw materials from China.

loans.name: Emm

texts.en:
A citizen from a rural village of Kampong Cham province’s Cheung Prey district, Emm is aged 58 years and married with four children. To make a living and support her family, Emm and her husband have been farming rice as primary business for 38 years and she supplements their income by working as a paid worker. The current business earns her about 50,000 KHR per day to support her family.

Emm is a first-cycled client with VisionFund. Now she is requesting a loan. She is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income from her current business so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Savan's Group

texts.en:
Savan is 55 years old and married with two children living in a rural village of Kampong Cham province’s Prey Chhor district. She and her husband earn a living through farming rice which they have been doing for 37 years. The current business earns them about 55,000 KHR per day and allows them to save about 32,000 KHR each day for their future needs. 

Savan has been with VisionFund for four cycles and completely paid back the past loans which have helped her better support her family with enough food. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy seeds for her farmland and use a portion of it to spend on plowing the field. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income from her rice paddy so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy seeds for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Saly's Group

texts.en:
Living in a rural area of the Srey Snom district of Siem Reap province, Saly is 34 years old with one kid. To make a living, Saly has been farming rice and raising cows. She can earn about 10,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s need. 

Saly has been with VisionFund for three cycles and completely paid back the past loans which have helped her better support her family. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to harvest rice. She hopes to get more crops from her rice paddy so as to better support her family with enough food.

loans.use: to harvest rice.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Sokrun

texts.en:
Sokrun is 29 years old and married. She lives with her family in a rural area located in the Kang Mean district of Kampong Cham province. She has two dependent children to take care of. Rice farming, sesame and bean growing are the primary sources of her family’s income to make a living and she has been in this business for eight years. With the current business, she can earn approximately 60,000 KHR per day and save about 20,000 KHR each day for future needs.

This is the first micro-loan for Sokrun with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Sokrun will use her loan to buy a plot of farmland. She hopes to extend her farmland.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Kang Meas District

loans.name: Solange

texts.fr: Solange est une femme de 44 ans mariée mère de famille. Elle est commerçante et fait la vente en détail des vivres frais (maniocs, plantains, patates et ignames) en fonction des saisons dans un marché de la place depuis 06ans. Elle a une bonne connaissance des fournisseurs, et surtout de sa clientèle qu'elle a acquise au fil du temps grâce à son expérience dans ce domaine. Mais elle se retrouve constamment en rupture de stock parce qu'elle est obligée de faire écouler tous le stock pour pouvoir s'en procurer à nouveau ceci à cause de la petitesse de son capital. Elle souhaitera augmenter son stock de vivres frais ce qui permettra de mieux satisfaire la demande constante de sa clientèle et d'éviter les ruptures de stocks. Elle économisera son bénéfice pour non seulement agrandir son activité mais aussi subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Solange is a 44-year-old married woman with children.  She has been buying and selling fresh produce (cassava, plantains, sweet potatoes and yams) seasonally, at a local market for six years.  She knows all her suppliers and customers very well thanks to her long experience in this field.  

Unfortunately, she often runs out of stock because she must sell all her produce before she has enough money to buy further supplies.  This is due to the very low level of her working capital.  Solange would like to increase her stock levels in order to be able to better satisfy the steady demands of her customers, and avoid the problem of running out of stock.

She will use her earnings to increase the size of her business and also to provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to increase her stock of fresh produce.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fish for resale.

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: Christine est une femme de 32 ans mariée mère de famille. Elle est commerçante et fait la vente en détail des vivres frais (maniocs, plantains, patates, ignames et fruits) en fonction des saisons dans un marché de la place depuis quelques années. Elle a une bonne connaissance des fournisseurs, et surtout de sa clientèle qu'elle a acquise au fil du temps grâce à son expérience dans ce domaine. Mais elle se retrouve constamment en rupture de stock parce qu'elle est obligée de faire écouler tous le stock pour pouvoir s'en procurer à nouveau ceci à cause de la petitesse de son capital. Elle souhaitera augmenter son stock de vivres frais ce qui permettra de mieux satisfaire la demande constante de sa clientèle et d'éviter les ruptures de stocks. Elle économisera son bénéfice pour non seulement agrandir son activité mais aussi subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Christine is a 32-year-old married woman with children.  She has been buying and selling fresh produce (cassava, plantains, sweet potatoes, yams and fruit) seasonally, at the local market for several years.  She knows her suppliers and customers very well thanks to her long experience in this field.

Unfortunately she often runs out of stock as she must sell all her produce before she can afford to buy further stocks.  This is due to the very low level of her working capital.  Christine would like to increase her stocks of fresh produce in order to be able to better satisfy the steady demands of her customers, and avoid running out of stock.  

She will save her earnings to expand her business and also provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to increase her stock of fresh produce.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
This is Leonila. She is 67 and a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is a widow with children. She and her children manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leonila operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5's worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns her money by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling goods individually. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Leonila hopes to be more successful in business and dreams to have a peaceful life. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell in her variety store business.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 71 years old and comes from Nakuru. She is blessed with three children who are adults.

She is a farmer who has been practicing mixed farming for the last 34 years.She has applied for her first loan of KES. 12,500 from VisionFund Kenya, which she will use to buy a water storage tank. With the water problem solved, she hopes to spend most of her time working in her farm as well as attending to her goats, in order to increase the farm's yield and profits.

She hopes to use the profits realized from her expanded business to pay back her loan to VisionFund Kenya and to buy more goats. In the future, she hopes to be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy a water storage tank

loans.name: Hin's Group

texts.en:
Hin is 29 years old and married with two children. She lives in a rural village of the Mongkul Borey district where crop farming is a common way to make a living. Like other villagers, rice farming has been her family’s main source of income for almost 10 years. She also catches fish to supplement her income. She can earn about 33,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 

Hin has been with VisionFund for two cycles and completely paid back the past loans which have helped her better support her family. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to pay to harvest rice. She hopes to make a more income from her current business.

loans.use: to pay to harvest rice.

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Perzilycer

texts.en:
Perzilycer is 28 years old and a single mother of two children aged six and two years .She runs an Agro Vet business in Kamelil trading centre in Nandi County. She has been in this business for the last three years and gets a monthly income of KES 20,000. 

She has borrowed KES 30,000. With this loan she will purchase herbicides, pesticides, maize seeds, beans seeds, animal drugs among other items based on her customers' needs. 

With the anticipated profits, she will increase her business stock, make some savings and repay her loan. Her dream is to give the best to her family i.e. meeting the financial needs and giving the best education to her children. She also wants to expand her business and open branches in other nearby towns as well as venture into a clothing business.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in south-western Kenya and borders onto Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. Populations are dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing and a few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay county is Ruma National Park, a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope, a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming, and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Lydia is married and has three children. She is a voluntary community worker and her husband is an IT specialist. Both she and her husband are farmers. They have been farming for ten years now and they are currently growing maize, beans, sorghum and keeping cattle. Lydia is excited about beekeeping because it will earn her some income and provide her with honey for medicinal use.

This is Lydia's first loan with Honey Care and she intends to use the proceeds from her beekeeping to expand her number of hives. Lydia's hope for the future is to have a commercial beekeeping project and produce more honey for the export market.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is a 33-year-old married woman living with her family in Lahore, Pakistan.

Her husband owns a bakery in his hometown. He sells different kinds of cakes, fresh cream cake, rusks, milk, biscuits and juices. He purchases the inventory in large quantities from a nearby bakery and sells the items in his own bakery. Now he wants to offer additional different types of bakery items to his customers but does not have sufficient cash in hand to buy them. 

Farida has requested a loan so that her husband can buy his desired bakery items to sell. Her husband's wish is to prepare these bakery items at home so that he can minimize the cost and maximize the income as well. He will start to make savings with the profit amount and hopes in future that he will be able to prepare all bakery items by himself. 

Farida gives thanks to Kiva and the field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy bakery items to sell in a bakery shop.

loans.name: Hoern's Group

texts.en:
Living in a wooden house located in the Srey Snom district of Siem Reap province, Hoern is aged 44 years and widowed. She has two children. To make a living, she has been raising pigs for five years. The current business earns them about 18,000 KHR per day and enables them to save about 13,600 KHR each day for future needs. 

Hoern is just with VisionFund for this cycle. She is now leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, Hoern is going to use her portion to renovate her old house. She hopes to have a decent house to live in.

loans.use: to renovate her old house.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 17 years old, single, and has one child. She lives in the town of Iganga, Uganda. For the past year, Aisha has been working hard to manage her clothing business, selling ladies' and men's clothes. 

To help expand her business, Aisha requested a loan from BRAC Uganda for 200,000 UGX, which she will use to purchase more clothes. The loan will help her to generate greater profits and save money to educate her child. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to open a retail shop.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is 29 years old and lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He is a hardworking and very honorable man, always committed to getting ahead.

All his life he has been working hard and earning money to assist his family. He is a kind man who works as a teacher making a low salary. He intends to buy home appliances for his house, but the amount he has is not enough to buy what he needs.

So, he is requesting a loan from AMB to buy home appliances and furniture to use in his house. He dreams of buying a taxi so that he can increase his income and improving his living standards.

loans.use: to buy home appliances and furniture to use in his house

loans.name: Sonoern

texts.en:
Sonoern, 49, lives in a rural village in Kampong Cham province’s Tbaung Khmum district, Cambodia. She is married and has three children.

For the last 30 years, Sonoern has been farming rice and working for others for a fee. She can earn about 39,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 
Sonoern has been with VisionFund for one loan cycle and completely paid back the past loan, which helped her better support her family with enough food. 

She is now requesting a loan. She will use her portion to build a decent house for living in. She hopes to have a bigger house for her family members.

loans.use: to build a decent house for living in

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Yong

texts.en:
Aged 51 years, Yong is married and lives with her family in a rural area located in the Tbaung Khmum district of Kampong Cham province. She is a mother of four children. She earns a living through farming rice and growing vegetables. Having been in this business for 31 years, she is able to earn about 15 USD per day to meet the family’s needs.

Yong has been with VisionFund for three loan cycles. Now she is asking for a loan. She will use her portion to buy a plot of farmland. She hopes to increase her rice crops so as to make a living better.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is 26 years old and lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He studies in college. He is a hard-working and very honorable man, always committed to getting ahead.  

All his life, Mohammed has been working hard and earning money to assist his family. He works as a soldier , making a low salary. He intends to buy home appliances for his house, but the amount he has is not enough to buy what he needs.

So he is requesting a loan from AMB to buy home appliances and furniture to use in his house. He dreams of improving his living standards.

loans.use: to buy home appliances and furniture to use in his house.

loans.name: Rona

texts.en:
A single woman with no children, 19-year-old Rona  lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Rona  has been working hard to manage her salon business, which offers hair-plaiting and styling services.

To help expand the business, Rona has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to buy more items for the salon such as chemicals. This will help her to generate greater profits, some of which she will use to provide for the basic needs of her family. Rona  hopes that in the future she will be able to further her studies.

loans.use: bto uy more items for the salon such as chemicals

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: Geraldine is a responsible housewife who engages in selling Avon, Natasha and MSE brand products within her community. She aims to strengthen the business and make it profitable in order to help her husband in providing the necessities of their family. She planned to acquire more stock of those products to sell, but she has limited capital. With regard to this, she is asking for an additional 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy the said additional stock to sell. Being kind and friendly, she believes that she will be able to sell more of her products.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of Avon, Natasha and MSE products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy extra clothes, incense and perfumes for her business.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr: Les quatre femmes du groupe Danaya sont mariées dans des familles polygamiques. Elles ont en moyenne  42 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes  dans le village de Banankoroniwere dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la République du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le village. Elles font le petit commerce, d’ustensiles et de restauration. Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 5eme  prêt solidaire. Madame Maratou 2 eme de la gauche vers la droite  est une grande restauratrice dans le village de Banankoroniwere et environ. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  150 kg de mil  au marché pour  la satisfaction du besoin de sa clientèle. Après transformation de ce mil en galettes, elle vend au comptant à la maison et au marché du village à une clientèle mixte. Madame Maratou  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé dans la prise en charge des petits  besoins des enfants et aider aussi son mari. Elle souhaitera, continuer le  partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The four women of the 'Danaya' Group are all married and live in polygamous families.  They are on average forty-two years old and have five children.  The women live in the village of Banankoroniwere, in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through family and business ties, and all work as kitchen utensil traders or in the restaurant business.

In order to improve their business capital, the group members work with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso, this will be their fifth group loan.

Maratou (second from the left in the photo) runs a large restaurant business in Banankoroniwere and its surrounding area.  She will use her loan to buy 150kg of millet from the market.  The millet will be used to prepare cakes which she will sell for cash, from her home and at the market.  She sells to a varied customer base.  Maratou expects to earn a monthly average of 15,000 francs CFA, and she will use this to help her husband and provide for some of the needs of their children.

In the future, Maratou would like to continue to work with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to buy millet to make cakes for sale.

loans.name: Nageena

texts.en:
Nageena is 31 and lives in Lahore with her husband and four children. 
Her husband has been running a barber shop for many years. He wants to buy new instruments and furniture, but his financial condition does not allow him to purchase the described accessories. Due to his low purchasing power, Zahida requested a loan to empower her husband, so he can easily buy new instruments such as scissors, combs, shaver, front mirror and revolving chair.
Nageena hopes that this loan will work positively and she would be able to make additional funds for household expenses. 
Nageena thanks Kiva and field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy chair, instruments and benches for barber shop.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is a 25-year-old single man who lives in Sana`a, Yemen. Approximately five years ago, Mohammed started his business, a grocery store selling staples. This business is Mohammed’s source of income so that he is able to give his family a better quality of life. Thanks to his good products and the good service that he offers, he has a large clientele, which allows him to have a very good level of sales. 

With the thought of generating more income and being able to offer his customers a greater variety of products, Mohammed wants to increase the stock of products that he has. However, he does not have enough capital to be able to buy the products from his providers. He therefore requested a loan of 200,000 YER (Yemen rials) from AMB that will give him the opportunity to buy food staples in order to stock his store and offer his customers a greater variety. He hopes that with the loan, he will be able to increase his sales because he will be offering his customers more products.

loans.use: to buy food staples in order to stock his store and offer his customers a greater variety.

loans.name: Silvan

texts.en:
Silvan lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya, and borders onto Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. Populations are dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing, and a few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay county is Ruma National Park, a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope, a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming, and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Silvan is married and has 10 children. His wife is a teacher while he is a retiree. Both he and his wife are farmers. They have been farming for 30 years now, and they are currently growing sunflower, maize, groundnuts, tomatoes, butternuts and vegetables. Silvan is excited about beekeeping because the bees will help in pollinating his crops, and because it will earn him some income.

This is Silvan’s first loan with Honey Care, and he intends to use the proceeds from his beehives to invest in his farming and pay for his children’s fees. Silvan’s hope for the future is to be able to refine honey locally.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located at the southwestern tip of Kenya, and its northern end is dominated by Lake Victoria, the largest lake in the Southern Hemisphere. Lake Victoria extends into three east African countries, allowing cross-border flows of goods and people, and a market day in a lakeside town in Homa Bay county often boasts traders from Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya, all of whom arrive in boats to ply their wares. Although the semi-arid nature of much of Homa Bay county means that poverty rates are quite high, many people in the region hold a strong cultural emphasis on education, and as a result school attendance figures around Homa Bay are above the national average.

Joseph is married and has five children. He is a church preacher, and his wife is a farmer. They have been farming for 10 years now, and they are currently growing potatoes, cassava, banana, maize, millet, pawpaw, passion fruit and mangoes in their farm. Joseph is excited about beekeeping as it will generate him some income and provide him with honey for food.

This is Joseph’s first loan with Honey Care, and he intends to use the proceeds from his beehives to pay for his children’s school fees. Joseph’s hope for the future is to expand his beekeeping project.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production

loans.name: Steven

texts.en:
Steven lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in south-western Kenya and borders Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. The population is dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing.  A few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. 

A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay county is Ruma National Park.  It is a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope which is a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Steven is married and has two children. He is a teacher and his wife is a social worker. Both are farmers. They have farmed for two years and they grow maize and beans. Steven is looking forward to beekeeping because it will earn him some income and provide him with honey for food.

This is Steven's first loan with Honey Care and he intends to use the proceeds from his beehives to start another project like poultry farming. Steven's hope for the future is to become a large scale bee farmer.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Gantsetseg

texts.en: Gantsetseg is 30 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. From 2006 to 2012 she had taught at elementary school. Since 2012 she has been running a creche using her previous experiences as a teacher. She has been able to attract lots of parents who are interested in day care services. She is requesting a loan of $2,050 to buy furniture such as tables, chairs and a sofa. She wants to make her creche more comfortable so that children may feel like they are at home.

loans.use: to buy furniture to make her creche more comfortable

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz requests a loan for her husband to sell ice cream in the evening to people in his area. He needs an ice cream making machine. 

He has a private job during the day but due to increased expenses, he wants to start a new business during the evening. 

Shahnaz is 38 years old and  lives in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of five children.
 
She hopes that with this new business, her husband would be able to earn additional income. She thanks  Kiva and theier field partner BRAC Pakistan team.

loans.use: to buy an ice cream making machine.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
"Betty is 22 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children who are all currently in school. For the past 3 years Betty has been working hard to manage her clothing / tailoring business, which sells ladies and gents clothing. 

To help expand the business, Betty has requested a loan of 950,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more material and clothing, and will help Betty to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Betty hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 




"

loans.use: buy more clothing and materials

loans.name: Ma. Liza

texts.en:
This is Ma. Liza, 45, a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Rufo, a pensioner, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ma. Liza operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-pesos worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also has a bakery for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 pesos in sales every day.

She is requesting a 30,000 pesos loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Ma. Liza dreams that her business will expand even more and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Eliakim

texts.en:
Eliakim lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located at the south-western tip of Kenya, and its northern end is dominated by Lake Victoria, the largest lake in the Southern Hemisphere. Lake Victoria extends into three east African countries, allowing cross-border flows of goods and people.  There is  a market day in a lakeside town in Homa Bay county which attracks traders from Ugandan, Tanzania and Kenya.  The traders arrive in boats to sell their wares. Although the semi-arid nature of much of Homa Bay county means that poverty rates are quite high, many people in the region hold a strong cultural emphasis on education. Therefore, school attendance figures around Homa Bay are above the national average.

Eliakim is married and has one child. He is a preacher and a businessman. His wife has a small business cooking and selling donuts. Both he and his wife are farmers. They have been farming for ten years  and  grow sunflowers, maize, cowpeas and beans. Eliakim is looking forward to beekeeping because it is a profitable business and it will provide him with honey for food.

This is Eliakim’s first loan with Honey Care and he intends to use the proceeds from his beekeeping to expand his business. Eliakim’s hope for the future is to expand his beekeeping project and to encourage his community to take up beekeeping.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Sory

texts.en:
Sory lives in a village near the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has four sons and one daughter. 

Sory raises cows, grows rice, and buys vegetable for resale. Her husband is a construction worker. 

Her husband travels to different places to work  and stays there sometimes. This travel costs lots of money and makes it  difficult for him to manage his income to support his family. 

Sory asks for a loan to buy a motorcycle for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for her husband to commute to work.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 22 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba, in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past two years, Justine has been working hard to manage her clothing business, in which she sells clothes. 

To help expand the business, Justine has requested a loan of UGX 200,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more children's clothes and will help Justine to generate greater profits and better feed her family. Justine hopes that, in the future, she will be able to start up a retail shop.

loans.use: to buy more children's clothes.

loans.name: Battsetseg

texts.en:
Battsetseg is 44 years old and lives with her two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They reside in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian dwelling. 

She has operated a local taxi service for 12 years. A previous loan helped her to renovate her house. She requests a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to buy appliances such as a television, washing machine and freezer. This will help to make her family's living environment more comfortable.

loans.use: to buy household appliances.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim is 18 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. 

For the past two years, Shamim has been working hard to manage her business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand the business, Shamim has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more children's clothes, and it will help Shamim to generate greater profits and develop her business. 

Shamim hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 




"

loans.use: to buy more children's clothes.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 22 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has two children with none of them currently in school. 

For the past year, Aisha has been working hard to manage her business, which sells shoes. 

To help expand the business, Aisha has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more shoes, and it will help Aisha to generate greater profits and buy necessities for her family. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to start a boutique.

loans.use: to buy more shoes.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
"Patricia is 16 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Lganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past year Patricia has been working hard to manage her restaurant business, which sells food. 

To help expand the business Patricia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food items for the restaurant and will help Patricia to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. Patricia hopes that in the future she will be able to to go for further studies. 




"

loans.use: buy more food items for the restaurant

loans.name: Janette

texts.en: Janette, 33 years of age, is married and blessed with two children. She owns and manages a restaurant in their village and earns a net income of PHP 1,500 daily. Her profits are usually spent on the school allowances of her children. Due to lack of capital to run a business like this, she would like to access a loan amounting to PHP 12,000 to purchase raw meat, chicken, fish, and vegetables to cook in her restaurant. She's hoping that her restaurant will continue to grow and become more profitable.

loans.use: to purchase raw meat, chicken, fish, and vegetables to cook in her restaurant.

loans.name: Zaulia

texts.en:
Zaulia is 40 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past one year, Zaulia has been working hard to manage her hostel, which is rented out. 

To help expand the business, Zaulia has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to expand the hostel buildings, and will help Zaulia to generate greater profits and expand the family business. Zaulia hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her assets.

loans.use: to expand the hostel buildings

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en:
Sylivia is 19 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 1 year, Sylivia has been working hard to manage her hotel business, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand the business, Sylivia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food items for the hotel and will help Sylivia to generate greater profits and buy basic needs for her family. Sylivia hopes that in the future she will be able to go back to school.

loans.use: to buy food items for the hotel.

loans.name: Evaline

texts.en:
Evaline is 18 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 1 year, Evaline has been working hard to manage her produce business, which sells produce. 

To help expand the business, Evaline has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more produce and will help Evaline to generate greater profits and pay for her house rent and siblings. Evaline hopes that in the future she will be able to to go for further studies.

loans.use: to buy more produce.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Nargis

texts.en:
Nargis is a 30-year-old married woman. She is living with her husband in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of two daughters and two sons. She is doing embroidery work by hand at home and financially supporting her family.
She belongs to a poor family; her husband’s income is very low so that she decided to start embroidery work at home. She learned these arts in her childhood and now has adopted them for her occupation. This has enabled her to be independent and earn sufficient income. She requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase stocks of threads, silk, fancy, sequins, and pearls of various colors. She hopes that this loan will prove beneficial for her and for her family. Nargis is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy embroidery material for knitting embroidery.

loans.name: Simnu Group

texts.en:
Simnu Group is formed by 14 women members living in the same village in Manipur, one of the northeastern states in India. The village is about 45 kms  from main capital town of Manipur. 

Chungyang, 45, is pictured with raised hand, and she is the featured borrower for the group. The group members are engaged in different income generating activity and they are all hardworking.

Chicken has been the only option for generating income for Chungyang. She had only a primary education that does not allow her to get a good governmental job. She stays at home and besides raising the chickens she manages the household affairs as her sons are not at home and her husband works on the farm. She takes keen interest in her chickens and also generates good income. She usually gets the chicken feeds from the main market and usually buys them in stocks.  

With the help of the KIva loan, she will purchase more chicks and raise them. Selling chicken is not a very difficult task. Buyers from the main market come down to the village where Chungyang lives and purchase them in large numbers. Demand is high and supply is insufficient because she could not raise large numbers. 

She wishes to build a larger coop for expansion of her chicken business. She says, "Thank you so much, Kiva, for giving me this opportunity to purchase chicks.” She says that she never dreamt that distant friends from the other side of the world would help her someday. She will also repay the loan on time and will work very hard to become the most successful poultry farmer.

The rest of the group members are also engaged in piggery and weaving.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks to raise.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 18 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 1 year, Mary has been working hard to manage her local brew business, which deals in local brew. 

To help expand the business, Mary has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials for making brew and will help Mary to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. Mary hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a retail shop.

loans.use: to buy more materials for making brew.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 21 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. 

For the past six years, Margret  has been working hard to manage her stationery shop, which sells books, pens, counter books, markers, toners, etc.

To help expand the business, Margret has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stationery items, and it will help Margret to generate greater profits and educate her siblings. 

Margret hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a supermarket.

loans.use: to buy more stationery items like books, pens, counter books, markers and toners.

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en:
Rosette is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kacwamba in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. For the past 8 years, Rosette has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand the business, Rosette has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for the business and will help Rosette to generate greater profits and increase on capital. Rosette hopes that in the future she will be able to have a well organized sustainable business.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for the business.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 19 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 1 year, Eva has been working hard to manage the food stall, which sells matooke. 

To help expand the business, Eva has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more matooke and will help Adele to generate greater profits and provide some of the basic needs for her family. Adele hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a retail shop.

loans.use: to buy more matooke.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 16 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 2 years, Jane has been working hard to manage her rice business, which deals in selling rice. 

To help expand the business, Jane has requested a loan of 350,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more rice and will help Jane to generate greater profits and develop herself. Jane hopes that in the future she will be able to to go for further studies.

loans.use: to buy more rice.

loans.name: Leyla Yardimciel

texts.en:
Leyla is married and has one child.  

She has worked as a hair stylist for 13 years. She studied hairstyling and accounting and began her career working at her family's business as an accountant. She worked for many years at the family company, but while she was working there, her mind was still on hairdressing.  

After her workplace was destroyed in an earthquake, she lost her job and had a difficult time. She worked in her cousin's beauty salon, which her cousin wanted to pass on. Her husband, knowing she liked hairdressing, surprised her by buying and giving her the salon. He told Leyla, "Now this place is yours."

After taking over the salon, she adding a waxing room, updated the furniture and added personal care (hair and skin care). She is pleased with the state of the salon now. She will buy supplies for the salon with the loan from Maya. She is satisfied with her work, she says. Now she aims to train her employees and teach them the business, profession and business ownership.
 
Translated from Turkish by Maya Staff 
Leyla Apaydın evli ve ,bir tane çocuğu var.  13 yıldır kuaförlük yapıyor.Kuaförlük ve muhasebe okumuş.  İş hayatına ailesinin iş yerleri olduğundan onların yanında muhasebeci olarak başlamış.  Uzun yıllar da aile şirketinde çalışmış.  Bu işi yaparken,aklı hep kuaförlükteymiş.  Depremde iş yerlerini kaybettiklerinden işsiz kalmış ve çok zor günler geçirmiş.  Şu an çalıştığı kuaför dükkanı ,kuzeninindi ve devretmek istiyordu.  Eşi kuaförlüğü sevdiğini bildiğinden,ona sürpriz yapmış ve kuzeniin devrettiği dükkanı alarak,dükkana getirmiş.  Leyla Hanım’a” burası artık senin “dedi.  Dükkanı devir aldıktan sonra ağda odası ekledi,mobilyalarını yeniledi,kişisel bakım(saç ve cilt bakımı)ekledi.  Şu an ki durumundan memnun.  Maya’dan aldığı kredi ile Kuaför dükkanına mal alacak.  İşinde doyuma ulaştığını söylüyor.  Şimdi ki amacı yanında elemanlar yetiştirip onlara mesleğini  öğretmek ,meslek ve iş sahibi yapmak.

loans.use: to buy supplies for the salon.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 50 years old and lives in the town of Kacwamba in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Florence has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells food. 

To help expand the business, Florence has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food to be stocked for the restaurant and will help Florence to generate greater profits and increase on her capital. Florence hopes that in the future she will be able to improve on her business.

loans.use: to buy food to be stocked for the restaurant.

loans.name: Silver

texts.en:
Silver is 50 years old and lives in the town of Kacwamba in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children with 3 of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Silver has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells essential goods for home use. 

To help expand the business, Silver has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential goods like soap, sugar, and salt and will help Silver to generate greater profits and increase capital for the shop. Silver hopes that in the future he will be able to have a big wholesale shop.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods like soap, sugar, and salt.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is a tricycle driver who runs a transportation business using his motorcycle. He has been in this business for almost five months and he usually earns about PHP 300 a day. He is 33 years old, married, and blessed with two children. He wants to give his family a better way of living and that's why he works hard. 

At this time, Edward is asking for a loan, amounting to PHP 5,000, to buy oil, sprockets, and gasoline for the maintenance of his motorcycle. He's hoping that his requested loan will be granted, so that he can fulfill his plan to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy oil, sprockets, and gasoline for the maintenance of his motorcycle.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 21 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has one child, who is currently in school. 

For the past year, Mary has been working hard to manage her business, which sells local brew. 

To help expand the business, Mary has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more brewing materials, and it will help Mary to generate greater profits and improve her life. 

Mary hopes that in the future she will be able to upgrade to a better bar.

loans.use: to buy more brewing materials.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn is married to a farmer and blessed with two children. She has owned and managed a retail store in their village for almost three years, earning a net income of PHP 800 daily. Her daily profits are usually spent on her hog raising business and her children's school allowances. Due to insufficient funds, she would like a loan amounting to PHP 15,000 to purchase cooking oil, soy sauce, vinegar, chips, detergent powder, and candies to sell. She is hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that she can expand and improve her business to earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, soy sauce, vinegar, chips, detergent powder, and candies to sell.

loans.name: Amilia Group

texts.en:
Amilia is a four-member group. All the members of the group are poor ladies from Taiz, Yemen. Together they applied for a 200,000 YER loan from AMB.

Yasmin is a 47-year-old married woman who has some children. She is the leader of the group. She is uneducated and living in a poor area in Taiz. Her house is very old and in miserable condition. The house is vulnerable to fall down at any time. It is known that house renovation requires a lot of money. She has started renovating her house, but now she needs more money in order to complete the renovation. She asked for a loan of 50,000 YER to buy cement and bricks. She hopes that after the completion of her house renovation, she can start accumulating money to improve the living conditions of her family and open a savings account.

loans.use: to buy cement and bricks to complete the renovation of her house.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya, close to both the Tanzanian border and Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake. Despite the proximity to the lake, water infrastructure in Homa Bay remains quite undeveloped, and inconsistent rains and occasional droughts make life difficult for farmers in the area. Nonetheless, farmers have adapted to these challenges, particularly by diversifying their crops to include cassava, sunflower, sorghum, bananas, groundnuts and millet, as well as drought-resistant varieties of papaya and mangoes. 

Although beekeeping has not traditionally been practiced in the region, many individuals have expressed interest in keeping bees and are knowledgeable about their pollination benefits.

Joseph is married and has ten children. He is a teacher and his wife runs a private school. Both he and his wife are farmers. They have been farming for 20 years now and they are currently growing maize, millet, beans and sweet potatoes. Joseph is looking forward to beekeeping as it will provide him with honey for medicinal use.

This is Joseph’s first loan with Honey Care and he intends to use the proceeds from his beehives to provide for his family’s basic needs. Joseph’s hope for the future is to have a successful beekeeping project and encourage more people to take it up as it will help to improve the environment and control deforestation.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Mumtaz

texts.en:
Mumtaz, age 53, is a responsible mother living in a congested house with a huge family in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of six children. 

She is taking loan for her son. He is a hawker by profession and sells hair oil via bicycle in the streets of his home town. His current stock of hair oil has depleted and he does not have cash in hand to buy fresh stock to sell. Therefore, Mumtaz requested a loan for her son so that he can buy hair oils to sell.

She hopes that her son will contribute for household expenses. Her dream is to pass her old age in peace and calm.

She is very thankful to Kiva and field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy hair oils.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay County is located in southwestern Kenya, close to both the Tanzanian border and Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake. Despite the proximity to the lake, water infrastructure in Homa Bay remains quite undeveloped, and inconsistent rains and occasional droughts make life difficult for farmers in the area. Nonetheless, farmers have adapted to these challenges, particularly by diversifying their crops to include cassava, sunflower, sorghum, bananas, groundnuts and millet, as well as drought-resistant varieties of papaya and mango. Although beekeeping has not traditionally been practiced in the region, many individuals have expressed interest in keeping bees and are knowledgeable about their pollination benefits.

Penina is a widow with seven children. She runs a food kiosk and also undertakes farming. She has been farming for 18 years now, and she is currently growing maize, sunflower, butternut, millet and vegetables. Penina is excited about beekeeping as it will earn her some income and provide her with honey for food.

This is Penina’s first loan with Honey Care, and she intends to use the proceeds from her beehives to pay for her children’s school fees. Penina’s hope for the future is to expand her beekeeping project and increase her honey production.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: La señora Ana Maria, comerciante desde hace varios años, ella vende refresco naturales, gaseosas, tortillas, y los fines de semana realiza fritangas, sus hijos la apoyan en el negocio, el creito lo solita para la compra de frutas para los refrescos e ingredientes varios como, azucar, bolsas, ademas comprara maiz para las tortillas y verduras y carnes para las fritangas que realiza, agradce el apoyo que se le ha brindado.
texts.en: Ms. Ana Maria, a merchant for several years, sells natural beverages, sodas, tortillas, and on the weekends she makes fried food. Her children support her business. She is asking for the loan to buy fruit for the beverages and various ingredients, such as sugar and bags. Additionally, she will buy corn for tortillas, and vegetables and meat for the fried foods she makes. She is grateful for the support that the Kiva network has provided.

loans.use: to buy fruit and various ingredients

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay County is located in southwestern Kenya and borders Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. Populations are dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing and a few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay County is Ruma National Park, a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope, a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming, and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Joyce is married and has ten children. She is a retired teacher. She runs a school in her community, and she also leads a mother’s union in her church. Both she and her husband are farmers. They have been farming for 30 years now, and they are currently growing maize, peas, beans, citrus fruits and mangoes and keeping a fish pond. Joyce is excited about beekeeping because it will provide her with extra income and honey for food.

This is Joyce’s first loan with Honey Care. She intends to use the proceeds from her beekeeping to pay school fees for her children and support the orphans in her school. Joyce’s hope for the future is to have a secure home.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay County is located at the southwestern tip of Kenya, and its northern end is dominated by Lake Victoria, the largest lake in the Southern Hemisphere. Lake Victoria extends into three east African countries, allowing cross-border flows of goods and people. A market day in a lakeside town in Homa Bay County often boasts traders from Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya, all of whom arrive in boats to ply their wares. Although the semi-arid nature of much of Homa Bay County means that poverty rates are quite high, many people in the region hold a strong cultural emphasis on education, and as a result school attendance figures around Homa Bay are above the national average.

Joseph is married and has seven children. He is a retired civil servant, and his wife is a teacher. Both he and his wife are farmers. They have been farming for five years now, and they are currently growing maize, bananas, citrus fruits, guavas, passion fruits and butternut squash. Joseph is looking forward to beekeeping as it will provide him with honey for food.

This is Joseph’s first loan with Honey Care, and he intends to use the proceeds from his beehives to pay school fees for his children. Joseph’s hope for the future is to expand his beekeeping project.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production

loans.name: Biath Al-Thallg Group

texts.en:
This group is called Biath Al-Thallg Group. It consists of four women who live in Taiz, Yemen. The members of this group are very trustworthy, responsible, hard workers. They have all known each other for a long time and they know each other well.  

Afaf is the group leader, 37 years old, a married woman who has four children. She has been operating a sewing business for many years. She chose this business because she has loved it since childhood. 

Because she is a professional in sewing, she asked for a loan of YER 40,000 from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank (AMB) to buy a sewing machine, women's fabrics, needles, etc., to grow her business and attract more customers.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine, women's fabrics, needles, etc., to grow her business and attract more customers.

loans.name: Marcos Manuel

texts.es:
Marcos es un señor casado de 30 años de edad, vive junto a sus cuatro hijos, de los cuales son; dos hombres y dos mujeres, ambos están estudiando y viven en el Departamento de Sololá.
El se dedica al cultivo de verduras a unos metros de su vivienda. El ahora cuenta con diez años de realizar esta labor, que le genera buenos ingresos y ganancias que le ayudan a contribuir a la economía de su familia. Como también comenta que en sus tiempos libres se dedica a manejar un taxi ya que es otro trabajo que le genera ingresos.
Por lo que ha tomado la decisión de solicitar un préstamo de Q 4,500.00 para la compra de materiales de construcción que servirá para su vivienda. El préstamo lo pagara con el trabajo que actualmente tiene.
Su mayor sueño es terminar la construcción de su vivienda para que su familia viva en mejores condiciones.
texts.en:
Marcos is a 30 year old married man.  He lives with his four children, of which two are boys and two are girls; they are all in school.  They live in the Sololá district.  He works growing vegetables just a few meters from his home.  He has been doing this work for the past ten years, and it generates a good income that helps him contribute to his family's finances.  In his free time, he also works as a taxi driver to earn additional income.

He has decided to seek a loan of Q 4,500.00 to purchase construction materials for his home.  He will pay back the loan with the job he currently has.  His biggest dream is to finish building his home so that his family can live in better conditions.

loans.use: purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya, close to both the Tanzanian border and Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake. Despite the proximity to the lake, the water infrastructure in Homa Bay remains quite undeveloped, and inconsistent rains and occasional droughts make life difficult for farmers in the area. Nonetheless, farmers have adapted to these challenges, particularly by diversifying their crops to include cassava, sunflowers, sorghum, bananas, groundnuts and millet, as well as drought-resistant varieties of papaya and mangoes. Although beekeeping has not traditionally been practiced in the region, many individuals have expressed interest in keeping bees and are knowledgeable about their pollination benefits.

Martha is married and has five children. She runs a small food kiosk. Both she and her husband have been farming for ten years now and they are currently growing maize, beans, butternut squash and millet on their farm. Martha is looking forward to beekeeping as it will earn her some income.

This is Martha’s first loan with Honey Care. She intends to use the proceeds from her beehives to pay her children’s school fees and renovate her house. Martha’s hope for the future is to have her children educated and to have good housing.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Juan Bladimir

texts.es: El señor Juan Bladimir, continua con sus planes de mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda, la parte trasera de la misma aun esta construida con Platicos, Zinc sobre todo el Baño y el inodoro, el credito lo solicita para comprar, Bloques, Hierro, Cemento. su esposa lo ayuda economicamente ya que es comerciante vende Tortilla, Sopa y Frojoles el es conductor de Mototaxi. Agradece el apoyo que se le ha brindado.
texts.en: Juan Bladimir continues with his plans to improve his home.  The rear part of this house is made of plastic and zinc, especially the bathroom and toilet.,  He is seeking this loan to purchase blocks, iron and cement.  His wife helps him financially as she sells tortillas, soup and beans.  He is a mototaxi driver.  He is grateful for the help that he has received.

loans.use: purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Lirije

texts.en:
Lirije wants to build a stable, and the amount she is requesting is 180,000 Albanian Lek. The shack in the background of the photograph is the existing stable. “It is very cold for my animals to sleep and stay in this type of stable. I feel so very sorry for my animals. When you’ve got animals, you automatically become attached to them and of course you think of them, just like you do for people. This is how I feel. I will be very grateful to lenders for any financial help they will provide to me through this loan.”

Lirije has two school-aged children, 18 and 10. Livestock has been the only activity and source of income for the family for the past ten years. This will be Lirije’s first loan.

loans.use: to build a stable for her animals.

loans.name: Julie Paulin

texts.es:
Ella es julie paulin estudia enfermería para llegar a ser jefe y tener una estabilidad económica buena.
Es la profesión que escogió con la cual tiene afinidad, necesita el convenio con kiva ya que el padre es el que paga los estudios y no tiene una economía solvente.
Esta es la carrera que  le gusta, la cual le ayudaría a salir adelante y con la cual podrá ayudar a mucha gente que lo necesite.
Espera que al terminar como auxiliar de enfermería, encontrar un trabajo y poder pagar el estudio como jefe de enfermeras.
La situación familiar en este momento no esta muy bien, ya que la mama tiene una enfermedad  degenerativa y el papa es el único que aporta dinero en la casa, el hermano menor también esta estudiando y necesita pagarle una pensión bastante costosa. 
Ella tiene una hija de 2 años y al no estar trabajando el papa tiene que responder por ella también.
Por la enfermedad que tiene la mama escogió esta carrera, para poder tener idea de como poder ayudarla a ella en  un futuro y tener estabilidad económica para la familia y la hija de ella.
Quiere entrar a la universidad y poder ser una jefe de enfermeras a si se incrementa un poco el dinero y aprenderá mas.
Con el esto ayudaría a los papas y sacaría adelante a la hija, ya que por ella tan pequeña necesita muchas cosas, así que con este descuento que kiva le hace le ayudaría mucho y podría seguir con el estudio.
texts.en:
She is Julie Paulin.  She is studying nursing in order to eventually become a boss and have a stable financial situation.  She chose this profession because she was drawn to it.  She needs the loan from Kiva because her father pay for her schooling, and is not financially solvent.  She enjoys this career, and it will help her get ahead and allow her to help many people in need.  She hopes that upon finishing her training as a nursing assistant, she will find a shop and be able to pay for her education as a head nurse.  

Her family situation is not very good at the moment.  Her mother has a degenerative disease and her father is the only one who contributes financially in the household.  Her younger brother is also studying and the father must pay a very expensive boarding fee for him.  She has a two year old daughter, and as she is not working, her father must support her as well.  She chose this career due to her mother's illness, so that she may have an idea of how she can help her in the future, and to be able to have some financial stability for her family and her daughter.

She wants to enroll in the university and become a head nurse, increasing her income a little and learning more.  This will help her parents and get her daughter ahead because at her young age, she needs many things.  This discount from Kiva will be very helpful and allow her to continue with her education.

loans.use: pay for a semester of school.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more oil, corn, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Debora lives in Ogongo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in southwestern Kenya and borders onto Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. Populations are dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing, and a few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay county is Ruma National Park, a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope, a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming, and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Debora is a widow with six children. She operates a small chemist shop and she is a farmer as well. She has been farming for twenty years now and she is currently growing maize, sunflower, beans, millet and groundnuts. She is excited about beekeeping as it will provide her with honey for medicinal use, especially in treating coughs, and because it will earn her some income.

This is Debora’s first loan with Honey Care. She plans to use the income from her beehives to expand her chemist business. Debora dearly appreciates the Kiva lenders because by their good will, they will enable her to realize her hope for the future, which is to have a healthy family and to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen is a 41-year-old woman, residing in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a mother of one daughter and three sons. 

Parveen is a simple housewife and her husband is running a crockery shop in the local market. Her husband wants to purchase different types of crockery (e.g., hot pots, plates, glasses, spoons, and dinner sets). But, due to insufficient financial resources, he is unable to purchase these items for the purpose of reselling.

Therefore, Parveen has applied for the Kiva loan from its field partner, BRAC Pakistan. Because of this loan, her husband will get help to purchase these items for business purposes. That will be very helpful to him, to increase daily sales and earn more profit.

Parveen is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy different types of crockery items to sell through her husband's business.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.es:
La señorita brenda es  una persona responsable, puntual, colaboradora, responsable.
