Jyotna’s husband has a bakery business, selling breads, cakes, various kinds of bakery items to the village shops but providing education for three children & running a household is very difficult for him due to low earnings. 
Now Jyotsna is taking the loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to afford all the tuition fees, schooling fees and to buy necessities for schooling for her son Shantanu studying in class X (grade 10). She wants to contribute in her son’s education so that he can run his studies smoothly to prosper in his life. Her son Shantanu is a hardworking and diligent student.
Jyotsna and her son Shantanu (standing beside Jyotsna) both are very ambitious and so they are thanking BJS and Kiva for their funding which will help them to fulfill their dreams.

loans.use: To afford all the tuition fees, schooling fees and to buy necessities for schooling for her son.

loans.name: Anima

texts.en:
Anima is a housewife while her husband Bhagirath is doing a small business in Maynaguri at Jalpaiguri district. Both of them are less educated but they are very much eager to educate their only daughter Mallika. She is in class VIII (grade 8).

Bhagirath’s business is not running well now and so he usually fails to submit her daughter’s school fees which create a great trouble in her school for promoting into the next class. As Mallika is a very good student and much sincere also, Anima becomes extremely worried because she thinks that she would not be able to give support to her daughter due to their present situation. At that time she heard about BJS (Kiva’s partner), organizations giving educational loan and she applied a loan of INR 13000 to meet all her daughter’s educational expenses so that she can establish herself in the society with high qualification.

Anima and her daughter Mallika (as in the photo) are now tension free and thanking BJS as well as Kiva for this financial support.

loans.use: To purchase all educational necessities for her daughter Mallika and pay all the fees related to her education.

loans.name: Rimah

texts.en:
Rimah is a 30-year-old married woman from a small village near the city of Nablus. She is the mother of two sons and one daughter. Her husband works in selling secondhand home appliances, for which he gets a low income. Rimah would like to start her own project, which is a sewing workshop. It is a good business and will help them to pay part of the family's expenses. 

Rimah took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy a new sewing machine for her project.  By taking this loan, Rimah will be able to start her own business. She would like to open a bigger sewing workshop in the future. Rimah appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Mays

texts.en:
Mays is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online. Her brother appears in the photo instead. Mays is a 19-year-old single young lady from Dier-Al-Balah city. She lives with her family in a very small simple house. Mays and her family work On their own project which is a restaurant for traditional food. They make food for parties and events. It is a good business and earns a good income. 

Mays took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her and her family to improve their restaurant and buy kitchen tools and an oven. This will increase the restaurant productivity and also the family income.

loans.use: to help her and her family to improve their restaurant and buy kitchen tools and an oven.

loans.name: Group (A)

texts.en:
“My anxiety to provide an education for my daughter this year has been helped by a Kiva and WSDS education loan,” shares grateful Neichong. She is the featured borrower member for Group (A) Group, and she is pictured with her daughter with their hands raised. She lives in a village, which is about 40 kms from the main capital town of Imphal, Manipur. The state is also one of the northeastern states in India.

Striving for basic needs does not allow Neichong to provide all the necessary materials for their children’s education. She usually pays for the admission fees and asks their kids to find used textbooks from seniors, and she gets the stationery supplies on credit from shops.  

The annual session usually starts just after the festival season ends, and that leaves a financial issue for a family whose income is irregular and meager. Borrowing from moneylenders was the only option available to let their kids pursue their studies. 

Neichong sells used garments, and her husband works in a private sector where the income is small and insufficient.

With the Kiva loan, she is providing admission fees, a set of school uniforms, textbooks, stationery supplies, and tuition fees for the whole year. She is so happy that her daughter can attend the school and not worry about the examination fees and others. She says, “Thank you so much, Kiva.” She will also try to repay the loan on time and will work very hard to keep their kids pursuing their studies, and give them a better future. She also says, “Kiva is such an inspirational organization, and (I) wish to continue this relationship for a long time.” 

The rest of the other group members are also providing admission fees, annual fees and other necessary expenses incurred. They all are thankful and grateful towards Kiva and WSDS.

loans.use: to pay for study materials and other necessary expenses for her daughter in pursuing her schooling.

loans.name: Zahida

texts.en:
Zahida is a 40-year-old married woman, living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of three children. She owns a clothing business. Her practice is to buy clothing from a wholesaler and sell it as a retailer. She has lot of lady customers who like to buy clothing from her. Her son purchases clothing from outside of the city to minimize the cost.
 
Demand from her customers is increasing day by day, but she does not have sufficient money to buy more clothing . Therefore, Zahida requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan, so that she would be able to buy more clothing to fulfill the demand.

She is in her repeated loan cycle and has been showing excellent repayment behavior. She has already been using the loan from BRAC to invest in the business. Her dreams are for the bright future of her children, the establishment of her business, and better living standards for her family. She is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Group (B)

texts.en:
Nengshi is the featured profile member for Group (B) Group and she is pictured with her daughter on the extreme left with their hands raised. Eight mothers joined hands and formed a group to take education loans. All of them had the same needs and desires to give their kids a good education, let them stand on their own feet and be successful. They live in a town that is about 40 km from the state capital of Manipur. Manipur is one of the northeastern states in India.
 
Nengshi shares that “a lump sum of money is like water in a desert for a parent like us “. Depending on the meager income generated from running a small grocery shop in the neighbourhood is difficult when you have five school-going kids.  The headache of the monthly fees is more when annual exams are to be held. Paying the monthly fees on a regular basis is difficult because at the beginning of the year, she usually gets money from money lenders at a high interest rate so that the kids don’t miss the session. But this usually paralyses her when its time to pay the monthly fees again. She is delighted to avail the loan from Kiva and says that she will repay the loan on time. She says, “Thank-you so much Kiva and WSDS for the wonderful gift” and she will always remain obliged for their help and assistance. The rest of the members are doing the same by providing admission fees, annual fees and other necessary educational expenses. They all are thankful and grateful to Kiva and WSDS.

loans.use: To pay for study materials and other school expenses for her daughter

loans.name: Taghreed

texts.en:
Because Taghreed is a conservative lady, she asked her daughter to take her place in the picture. Taghreed was born in 1969. She is married and lives in an area of Jordan called Wihdat with her husband and three daughters. For seven years, she has been trying her best to support her husband improve their living conditions and cover their daughters’ needs by running her project selling clothes and blankets from her house. 

She needs to expand it more now by buying a larger quantity of clothes and blankets and adding variety to them in order to attract more customers and to raise her profit. But she doesn't have enough money to do so. For this reason, she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and blankets for her business.

loans.name: Rutooma Tweyombekye2 Group

texts.en:
The Rutooma Tweyombekye Group is located in Rutooma Town. The group is comprised of mainly women some are married, some are widows, and a few are single mothers.

Mildred is a married mother with four kids; her husband is a teacher whose salary is not enough to maintain the family. She also takes care of her sisters’ two daughters who were abandoned by their mother. 

Mildred runs a small drug store with limited capital. Besides that, she also has a small banana farm where she gets income to boost her drug store business. She applied for a loan of 1,200,000 UGX  so as to add more capital to her  drug store. She plans to use the rest of the money to pay school fees for her children and for basic needs in life since her husband's salary is inadequate.

Her major challenges are insufficient capital to boost her business and thieves who steal her bananas which affects her cash flow. Despite these challenges, Mildred  has been able to provide good education and basic needs for her children.

loans.use: To buy drugs for the pharmacy

loans.name: Marvin Leodan

texts.es:
Marvin, vive con su compañera de vida y un hijo, desde niño aprendió de su padre a sembrar granos básicos, actualmente lo realiza como una forma de generar ingresos para cubrir los gastos familiares, también se dedica a la comercialización de cerdos.
Utilizara el crédito para comprar cerdos y la recolección de la cosecha, fortalecerá el negocio lo suficiente para tener mejores ganancias con las que cancelara las cuotas de la deuda y ofrecer a su familia un mejor estilo de vida.
Sueña con tener un área de cultivo más grande para continuar trabajando y mejorar sus condiciones económicas.
texts.en:
Marvin lives with his life partner and his son.  When he was a child, his father taught him to cultivate staple grains.  Now he does this work as a way to generate income to cover the family's expenses.  He also works raising and selling pigs.

Marvin will use this loan to buy pigs and to harvest his crops. This will fortify his business enough so that he will have the earnings to pay off the debt and provide his family with a better standard of living.

Marvin dreams of having a bigger plot of land to cultivate so that he could continue to work and improve his financial situation.

loans.use: to buy pigs and harvest his crops

loans.name: Asaph

texts.en: Asaph, a married man with five children, depends entirely on agriculture to earn a living and for the livelihood of his family. From crop husbandry and banana growing, he feeds the family and sells the surplus to get income. He also rears goats that appreciate in value, as well as when others give birth. The demand for goat meat is high, so when he has a large stock of goats, then he is assured of income. He is hard working and strives to provide for his family. He thanks UGAFODE (UGAFODE Microfinance Limited) for helping the unbanked and marginalized to be served. In the photograph is Asaph(left) with the Ugafode credit officer at his farm.

loans.use: to buy goats for rearing and selling later.

loans.name: Medard

texts.en:
Medard is an old client in the institution. He has applied for a loan of UGX 1,700,000 as a top–up to buy a motorcycle. He has already deposited part of the payment, and will complete the payment using the loan money. 

He operates a transport business in Rukungiri Town, but he comes from a rural area in Ndorero - Southern Division in Rukungiri Municipality.

His challenge has been riding other peoples’ motorcycles, and therefore using most of the money to pay the owner. With this loan facility, he will buy his own motorcycle, which he hopes will increase his income base to sustain himself and his family.

He hopes to grow his income and change from motorcycle riding, commonly known as “Boda Boda”, to taxi transport if he gets enough income.  In the photograph is Medard with the Ugafode credit officer in a tie.

loans.use: to top up the payment to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone, solar charging set and a weighing scale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone, a solar charging set and a weighing scale to use in rendering services as a Community Knowledge Worker.

loans.name: Gerald

texts.en:
Gerald is 34 years old with seven children. He lives in a rural setting with his family and four of his children attend school. His children are aged 2, 5,7 and 9 years.

Gerald is a farmer who deals in agriculture, specifically the growing of coffee and passion fruits. He works six days a week and each day he works for 12 hours.  He has been in the agriculture business since 1997 and he supplements his family income with a bar, which he operates at night  He started his business in order to earn a living since he dropped out of school at an early age. He has acquired this loan in order to boost his business by buying fertilizers and insecticides, which will help him to harvest a high quantity of high quality goods, which will attract more customers and increase his income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a 39-year-old male. He is married with six children, aged 20, 18, 17, 15, 13 and 10 years old, whom he supports. This is his seventh loan of KES 100,000.

He was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by the VisionFund officer. He does bicycle repairs and services. He has been in this business for seven years, and he earns a monthly income of KES 20,000. 

He’s planning to use the loan to purchase more spare parts to use to repair bicycles for his customers. He will use the profit to buy a shamba (a garden or farm). His hopes and dreams for the future are to build rental houses and educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase more spare parts to use to repair bicycles for his customers.

loans.name: Safari

texts.en: Safari is a resident of katete a village in Mbarara district aged 45 years. He studied and graduated with bachelor’s degree in law but later failed to get a job. Pushed by the need to survive, he settled at their home and started serious vegetable farming. This business grew and helped him to sustain his father’s family and supporting education for his young brothers. He later obtained a loan of UGX 3,000,000 from Ugafode which has helped him to start constructing a house together with his savings. He is requesting for another loan of 3,000,000 to help him finish the house. He is optimistic the new house will provide modest accommodation to his house hold members.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Fatima

texts.es:
Fatima trabaja como encargada de una Cabina Telefónica, vive sola, pues sus padres son del interior, y ella vino a la capital para poder estudiar y salir adelante.
Comenta que sus metas futuras son trabajar en su profesión, que es la de Kinesiología y poder especializarse en otra áreas de la medicina. Con esto espera realizarse profesionalmente y también lograr su progreso y el bienestar de su familia.
Ella pide este préstamo para poder pagar sus cuotas y de esa forma poder seguir estudiando.
texts.en:
Fátima's the manager of a telephone center.  She lives alone because her parents are from the interior and she came to the capital to study and get ahead.

She says her goals for the future are to work in her profession, kinesiology, and be able to specialize in other areas of medicine.  She hopes to be an accomplished professional and bring progress and well-being to her family.

Fátima's asking for this loan so she can pay her fees and keep on studying.

loans.use: to pay her fees

loans.name: San Francisco Group

texts.es:
San Francisco es un grupo que gracias a su esfuerzo y trabajo ya está en su ciclo 13 de programa de comités, además de eso forman también parte del programa de la eliminación de la pobreza, que les permite conocer cómo se encuentra cada una y conforme a ello poder mejorar su calidad y estilo de vida, no solo de ellas sino también de su familia.
Ana es parte de este grupo, y comenta que entre los trabajos que ella hacen esta la confección de pantallas y sombreros hechos de Karanday,  que en esta época hay mayor venta , también se debe destacar el trabajo que todas hace, ya que ponen su mayor esfuerzo por poder crecer.
La Sra. Ana solicita de este crédito para la compra de sus materiales, como ser Karanday, hilos, pegamentos y demás lo que le ayudará a tener a concretar su plan de negocio, el cual le ayudará a mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
San Francisco Group, thanks to its effort and work, is in its thirteenth loan cycle with the committee program.  They're also part of the poverty-elimination program, which allows them to know where each one stands and how they can improve their quality of life and lifestyle, not only for themselves but also for their families.

Ana's part of this group.  She said one of the jobs she does is making screens and hats of karanday fronds, which sell better this time of year.  She also pointed out the good work that all the members do, because they put their best effort into being able to grow.

Ana's requesting this loan to buy karanday fronds, thread, glue, and other supplies.  This will help her firm up her business plan and improve her income.

loans.use: to buy karanday fronds, thread, glue, and other supplies
